posts.name: Kevin williams
posts.cooked: Just curious is there an alternative gearbox that can be used with the Andymark climber In a box.  Some of the sport boxes will the ratio we need are out of stock.

posts.name: Ben Ketchum
posts.cooked: You could probably use a versaplanetary gearbox from Vex. I havenâ€™t looked in CAD to see if everything would line up mounting wise, so that should be checked first. But you can make close to whatever ratio you are looking for.

posts.name: Garrett Calkins
posts.cooked: I would not use a versaplanetary in the climber. They are not designed to stand up to those kind of loads. You could make a custom gearbox to replace one of the side plates at the base of the climber that uses regular spur gears and a neo / falcon / cim motor. We did this for our prototype with the climber in a box, using a 12t steel cim motor pinion mounted on a Neo, and a 60T gear driving the spool, both gears from vex. This was able to lift the full weight of a robot pretty easily in out tests.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
We just used a Max Planetary. We did not get the gear ratio correct yet 4:1 with one Neo just lifted it a few inches, but I am pretty sure it will handle the torque.

In addition, you could use a toughbox mini, but you may need to get creative with mounting options.

posts.name: Ben Ketchum
posts.cooked:
Ya,I personally would machine a custom gearbox, but I donâ€™t know what resources every team has so I suggested a versaplanetary.

We have used them without fault on climbers in many seasons past with max weight robots. As long as you donâ€™t use the versa lite gearbox that is.

posts.name: Garrett Calkins
posts.cooked: we were able to make the gearbox pretty quickly using a drill press and a pair of calipers. Way faster for us in a quick prototype then modeling up a gearbox and then making it on one of our CNC machines.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Just stick to the 3:1, 4:1, and 5:1 stages and itâ€™ll be fine unless you decide to find some way to send some nasty shock loading through the system.

posts.name: Cory Walters
posts.cooked: Same, used VP for all our robot lifting devices. Even used it for two robots in 2018.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Assuming youâ€™re minimizing shock loads, the only real issue I see with a Versaplanetary is that the shafts are less than 1.6" long, and youâ€™ll want the end of the shaft supported in the bearing to deal with the lateral torque on the gearbox.  You could cut a length of thunderhex, bore it out to 1/4" and use it as  an extension, securing with a 1/4"-20 bolt.  Far from ideal, but way better than not supporting the spool from the end.  And as @Skyehawk suggests, stick to the smaller ratios, especially for the output stage.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
A. I agree that supporting the far side of the output shaft is a very good idea if youâ€™re going to use a Versaplanetary gearbox. The lateral loads will likely obliterate your gearbox if you leave it cantilevered in lifting situations.

B. Any gearbox can be supplemented with either chain, belts, or gears to get you whatever reduction you need.

C. It is possible (though usually takes some practice to get right) to make a good-enough-for-a-few-hundred-uses gearbox using some plate, calipers, compass, a punch, a drill press, a pilot drill, and a step drill. Iâ€™d never trust them for a continuous use like a drive train, but for a once-a-game lifter they can do the job just fine. Chain/belts will do just as well but typically have a much bigger footprint and weight cost to them. [Iâ€™m not confident enough in my abilities to want to try to make more than a single reduction gearbox by hand, but our CnC router crapped out just as we were designing our PTO this year, so off we wentâ€¦]

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
pfreivald:

It is possible (though usually takes some practice to get right) to make a good-enough-for-a-few-hundred-uses gearbox using some plate, calipers, compass, a punch, a drill press, a pilot drill, and a step drill. Iâ€™d never trust them for a continuous use like a drive train, but for a once-a-game lifter they can do the job just fine.

Yup, lots of people seem to forget the lifespan of an FRC robot is measured in hours.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
They also seem to forget that not only do gearboxes predate CnC mills, they predate millsâ€¦

If youâ€™ve got the technology at your fingertips, by all means use it and do things the right way; but if you donâ€™t, you can old school a lot of stuff and get great results.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
pfreivald:

they predate millsâ€¦

Rephrasing a bit:

Which came first, the gearbox, or the mill?

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked:
pfreivald:

It is possible (though usually takes some practice to get right) to make a good-enough-for-a-few-hundred-uses gearbox using some plate, calipers, compass, a punch, a drill press, a pilot drill, and a step drill. Iâ€™d never trust them for a continuous use like a drive train, but for a once-a-game lifter they can do the job just fine. Chain/belts will do just as well but typically have a much bigger footprint and weight cost to them. [Iâ€™m not confident enough in my abilities to want to try to make more than a single reduction gearbox by hand, but our CnC router crapped out just as we were designing our PTO this year, so off we wentâ€¦]

One of my favorite gear box tricks is the Andymark AM 4166 the double bearing plate. It gives you a 70T spacing for 20dp gears. The bearing holes, in the wood, polycarb or whatever, can be oversized and not have perfect spacing.  Match drill the 2" circle bolt holes and you are good to go.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Iâ€™d go with MaxPlanetarys over VersaPlanetaries any day for a climber. They are the same price and the MPs are substantially beefier.

We used two Max Planetaries at 16:1 for our climbing spools and they are doing great. One for each side, since we have a two-sided climber. I highly, highly recommend this product as a compact and simple solution.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: â€¦and another way to â€œgear downâ€ your winch system is to use a smaller diameter drum on your winch (although strength comes into play at some point.)

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
pfreivald:

strength comes into play

Probably before that would be the diminishing returns from the diameter increasing due to the cord wrapping unless you have a rather long drum.  If you wrap 32" of 1/4" rope on a drum 1" wide (measured between the flanges) and very small, even assuming you get it wound reasonably level and efficiently, the final diameter would be about 1.6".  A 3/4" diameter drum (like, a hex spacer) only brings it up to 1.8".  The gains are even less when you take non-level winding into account. The AM Climber winch kit [which I assume OP is using] appears to have a drum diameter of 7.87" as the difference between the 1-1/2" and 2" drums is a AM -3948-500 hex spacer.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked: Rightâ€“but the difference between a 3/4" drum and a 3" drum is non-trivial.
